Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates by suggesting that security improvements to the White House fence in 2015 included the introduction of Islamic symbolism to the design.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support as it does not provide any evidence or credible sources to back up the assertion.
Problematic assumption: The claim makes a problematic assumption by linking the security upgrade to Islamic symbolism without any factual basis.
Exist alternative explanation: The expert's verdict provides an alternative explanation by stating that the "Islamic" elements of the design had been in place for at least 100 years, suggesting that they were not a recent addition.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that the security upgrade consisted only of adding removable spikes and did not involve any changes to the existing design elements.
Falters at times: The claim falters at times by relying on unreliable web sources and anti-Muslim bloggers to support its assertion.
Understate: None of the biases in the expert's verdict can be categorized as understating the claim.
